You can save the results into a text file using the PrintWriter class and its write method. Here's an example of how you can modify the code to save the number of times X and O win into a text file:

```java
import java.awt.*;
import java.awt.event.*;
import javax.swing.*;
import java.io.*;

public class XO2 implements ActionListener {
    private int[][] winningCombination = new int[][] {
        {0, 1, 2},
        {3, 4, 5},
        {6, 7, 8},
        {0, 3, 6},
        {1, 4, 7},
        {2, 5, 8},
        {0, 4, 8},
        {3, 4, 6}
    };
    private JFrame window = new JFrame("Tic Tac Toe");
    private JButton buttons[] = new JButton[9];
    private int count = 0;
    private String letter = "";
    private boolean win = false;
    private int xWins = 0;
    private int oWins = 0;

    public XO2() {
        window.setSize(300, 300);
        window.setDefaultCloseOperation(JFrame.EXIT_ON_CLOSE);
        window.setLayout(new GridLayout(3, 3));
        for (int i = 0; i < 9; i++) {
            buttons[i] = new JButton();
            window.add(buttons[i]);
            buttons[i].addActionListener(this);
        }
        window.setVisible(true);
    }

    public void actionPerformed(ActionEvent a) {
        count++;
        if (count % 2 == 0) {
            letter = "O";
        } else {
            letter = "X";
        }
        JButton pressedButton = (JButton) a.getSource();
        pressedButton.setText(letter);
        pressedButton.setEnabled(false);
        for (int i = 0; i < 8; i++) {
            if (buttons[winningCombination[i][0]].getText().equals(buttons[winningCombination[i][1]].getText())
                    && buttons[winningCombination[i][1]].getText().equals(buttons[winningCombination[i][2]].getText())
                    && !buttons[winningCombination[i][0]].getText().equals("")) {
                win = true;
            }
        }
        if (win == true) {
            JOptionPane.showMessageDialog(null, letter + " Won!");
            if (letter.equals("X")) {
                xWins++;
            } else {
                oWins++;
            }
            try {
                PrintWriter writer = new PrintWriter("results.txt");
                writer.write("X wins: " + xWins + "\n");
                writer.write("O wins: " + oWins + "\n");
                writer.close();
            } catch (IOException e) {
                e.printStackTrace();
            }
            System.exit(0);
        } else if (count == 9 && win == false) {
            JOptionPane.showMessageDialog(null, "Draw!");
            System.exit(0);
        }
    }

    public static void main(String[] args) {
        XO2 starter = new XO2();
    }
}
```

<<<explanation>>>: 
In the actionPerformed method, after checking if X or O wins, we increment the respective win count (xWins or oWins). Then, we create a PrintWriter object and pass the file name "results.txt" to it. We use the write method of PrintWriter to write the number of X and O wins into the file. Finally, we close the PrintWriter. Note that we handle any IOException that may occur during the file writing process.
